Literature Review: Synthetic biology has emerged as a transformative field that combines engineering principles with biological systems, aiming to create novel functionalities and explore fundamental questions about life. This review focuses on recent advancements in genome resynthesis, synthetic genetics, and orthogonal biosystems, highlighting their potential to revolutionize our understanding of biological processes and address global challenges.Genome resynthesis represents a significant milestone in synthetic biology, allowing researchers to redesign and construct entire genomes from scratch. The Synthetic Yeast Genome Project (Sc2.0) stands out as a pioneering effort in this domain. Richardson et al. (2017) reported the successful synthesis of five chromosomes of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, demonstrating the feasibility of large-scale genome engineering. This achievement opens up possibilities for creating organisms with tailored properties and studying the minimal requirements for life.Building upon genome resynthesis, synthetic genetics aims to expand the genetic alphabet beyond the natural four-letter code. Hoshika et al. (2019) introduced an eight-letter genetic system that includes four additional nucleotides, effectively doubling the information density of DNA. This expanded genetic alphabet not only enhances our understanding of the chemical basis of heredity but also presents opportunities for developing novel therapeutics and nanomaterials.The concept of unnatural base pairs (UBPs) has been instrumental in expanding the genetic code. Zhang et al. (2017) successfully incorporated a synthetic nucleobase pair into the genome of Escherichia coli, demonstrating the potential for creating semi-synthetic organisms with enhanced capabilities. This breakthrough paves the way for engineering organisms with novel amino acids and proteins, potentially leading to new catalysts and materials.Orthogonal biosystems represent another frontier in synthetic biology, aiming to create biological components that operate independently of natural systems. Ostrov et al. (2016) reported the successful recoding of the E. coli genome, replacing all instances of one codon with synonymous alternatives. This approach not only provides insights into genetic code evolution but also creates opportunities for biocontainment and virus resistance in engineered organisms.The development of xenobiotic nucleic acids (XNAs) has further expanded the realm of synthetic genetics. Pinheiro et al. (2012) demonstrated the capacity of synthetic polymerases to replicate and evolve six different XNAs, showcasing the potential for creating artificial genetic systems with properties distinct from natural DNA and RNA. These XNAs could find applications in nanotechnology, diagnostics, and therapeutics.Advancements in genome synthesis technologies have been crucial for realizing these ambitious projects. Chou et al. (2021) introduced a method for high-fidelity DNA synthesis using enzymatic approaches, addressing limitations of traditional phosphoramidite chemistry. This technique enables the production of longer DNA sequences with fewer errors, facilitating the construction of synthetic genomes and complex genetic circuits.The expansion of the genetic code has also led to the incorporation of non-canonical amino acids into proteins. Chin (2017) reviewed recent progress in this field, highlighting the potential for creating proteins with enhanced or entirely novel functions. This capability opens up new avenues for protein engineering, drug development, and the study of protein structure and function.Orthogonal translation systems represent another important aspect of synthetic biology. d'Aquino et al. (2018) developed an orthogonal ribosome-messenger RNA pair in E. coli, enabling the site-specific incorporation of unnatural amino acids without affecting the native proteome. This technology provides a powerful tool for studying protein synthesis and creating novel biological functions.As synthetic biology continues to advance, ethical considerations and biosafety measures become increasingly important. Gleizer et al. (2019) reported the creation of a synthetic CO2-fixing organism, highlighting both the potential for addressing climate change and the need for responsible development of synthetic life forms.In conclusion, the expanded central dogma of molecular biology, encompassing genome resynthesis, synthetic genetics, and orthogonal biosystems, represents a paradigm shift in our approach to understanding and engineering biological systems. These advancements not only deepen our knowledge of the fundamental principles of life but also offer unprecedented opportunities for addressing global challenges in health, energy, and the environment. As the field continues to evolve, interdisciplinary collaboration and careful consideration of ethical implications will be crucial for realizing the full potential of synthetic biology.
